revised_title: The Role of Cavities in the Initiation and Growth of Explosions in Liquids
tldr: This study investigates the role of cavities in the initiation and growth of explosions in liquids, focusing on the transition from deflagration to faster reactions in liquid explosives. The authors found that cavities and air bubbles can cause a transition to fast reactions in nitroglycerine and help sustain it through various processes, such as adiabatic collapse, increased burning surface area, and jetting. The research also explores the importance of confinement and the presence of discontinuities in the explosive.
